item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

The Wanderer:

I know, but I was confused on what you meant was different about the subject relating to the GPU. Doesn’t matter anyways. Does the Java Certificate changing have anything to do with this?

It shouldn’t. They’re still using the Java client. If anything, a new certificate reinforces that they’re continuing use of their Java client. They probably just needed to renew it.

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:42, topic:457166”][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=560101.msg4097847#msg4097847 date=1347067073]
are you saying the html5 client will be loaded onto the gpu or normally games will and this won’t be the case if they are doing what you think they are?
[/quote]

Huh? The GPU is just for storing graphical information. WebGL allows you to do this just as much as a native GL application, minus newer GL/DX features. Your question is confusing. :s[/quote]
Sorry, I’ll try to clarify. I was confused what you meant originally at this

but the majority of processing in modern game engines should be on the GPU.
Are you saying it won't be in this case with RS using WebGL? Or that it isn't the case right now, but when the HTML5 client comes out it will. Or am I completely misinterpreting what you were saying? :P

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

The Wanderer:

are you saying the html5 client will be loaded onto the gpu or normally games will and this won’t be the case if they are doing what you think they are?

Huh? The GPU is just for storing graphical information. WebGL allows you to do this just as much as a native GL application, minus newer GL/DX features. Your question is confusing. :s

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:37, topic:457166”]It wont be 3-4gb as a lot of average people (that aren’t crazy about computers) wont have that.
The requirements will go up overtime but it will be steady and a lot of people should be able to keep up with it. Their are always second hand PCs out their for a cheap price that can play the game.[/quote]

This. All “old” computers used to play RuneScape now are likely fully webgl capable. They can support the subset of OpenGL which covers GLES 2.0, and thus, webgl. All they need to do is install a html5-compliant browser, giving them the ability to play with this new RS game engine. If anything, it’s makes RuneScape more accessible than ever before. Besides the massive infrastructure changes it requires of the engine development team, it’s a very wise move for Jagex. They are going to have one of the first major games distributed using HTML 5.

Also, Loveandpower, I think you will find the HTML 5 client will probably run a bit better than the Java version. Although most of it will be operated using Javascript (at least, in theory, it’s hard to tell for sure how they’re going to make some of those decisions), but the majority of processing in modern game engines should be on the GPU. We’ll see how this goes, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:5, topic:457168”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=560101.msg4091493#msg4091493 date=1346431541]

So I talked to a jmod and he has confirmed that the system requirements will probably be going up soon. So those of us who are to poor to do anything are pretty much screwed

The max requirements will probably be going up. Jagex has remained rather adamant about backward support for their game. Most companies would not even bother writing an entire software rendering system just for those whose graphics cards can’t handle the game (ie, non-gaming laptops, which shouldn’t even be playing games anyway). I’m sure they will provide settings for turning down draw distance or using less resourceful lighting. Don’t be too concerned about it, unless you want to run the highest settings.
[/quote]Well the current requirements minimum is supposed to be 1gb for efficient safe mode. They said it will be probably be going up to 2gb. The suggested was 2gb and will be either 3-4gb probably[/quote]

It doesn’t really scale like that, though.

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

So I talked to a jmod and he has confirmed that the system requirements will probably be going up soon. So those of us who are to poor to do anything are pretty much screwed

The max requirements will probably be going up. Jagex has remained rather adamant about backward support for their game. Most companies would not even bother writing an entire software rendering system just for those whose graphics cards can’t handle the game (ie, non-gaming laptops, which shouldn’t even be playing games anyway). I’m sure they will provide settings for turning down draw distance or using less resourceful lighting. Don’t be too concerned about it, unless you want to run the highest settings.

Read full topic

item.title: Future update screenshots
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:22, topic:457166”][quote author=BloodRayne link=topic=560101.msg4090671#msg4090671 date=1346298617]

the HTML5 client is going to be a huge boost for them.

Was thinking the same, opens up the game to many new(specifically mobile?) platforms if I’m not mistaken :o
[/quote]

Most mobile platforms do not support webGL yet, However if they can get the framerate on the standard canvas then yes. but its going to have to be faster than: http://silabsoft.org/pos3d/index.html[/quote]

They will, lol. WebGL is just based on OpenGL ES 2.0, which most platforms do support. It’s up to the browsers being updated to support the link between HTML5 WebGL and the GLES20 implementation. There’s no point in doing a software-driven rendering system using canvas, except seeing if it’s possible I suppose.

Read full topic
